Replace disposable air filters.
A cleanable air filter is advertised as “washable” “permanent” and/or “reusable”. Don’t wash paper or otherwise disposable air filters.
Avoid vacuuming them as well.
Washing disposable air filters can actually clog them as well as cause mold.
Disposable filters can tear under the pressure of vacuuming or compressed air.
At a low pressure this may work temporarily but it’s not a long-term solution.
Clean or replace your car air filter regularly.
Clean or change your filter every 12000 to 15000 miles or more often if you travel on dusty roads or in polluted areas.
Disposable filters should be replaced whereas permanent filters can be vacuumed or washed.
If you don’t change your air filter as needed you may notice a decrease in your gas mileage ignition problems or fouled spark plugs.
Clean or replace your home air filter routinely.
Clean or change your filter every three months and more frequently in-season.
Clean or change the furnace filter monthly during the heating season.
If your filter is disposable replace it.
If it’s reusable you can vacuum or wash it.
More frequent changing is needed if your filter is exposed to a lot of dust or pet hair.
Failing to clean your air filters in the home can cause HVAC failure or even fire.

Use ribbons or push pins to fix the evergreen branches to your front door.
If you like tie a red ribbon around the branches to give them the look of a seasonal bouquet.

**Refurbished Furniture Decorating Tips**

1. Turn an old combination radiophonograph in a beautifully veneered cabinet into an elegant foyer console.
2. Use drums as tables by bunching together a trio of tribal drums and using them as individual coffee tables.
3. Discreet furniture never reveals its source (garage sale or heirloom?) but adds to a room’s overall beauty and comfort.
4. Create an instant slipcover by throwing a king-size sheet quilt or bedspread over an unsightly sofa and tying it in place with rope or grosgrain ribbon.
5. Decorate an old chest for a teenage boy's room with discarded license plates.
6. Nail them into place.
7. Decoupage an old dresser or dressing table with motifs cut from wallpaper.
8. Safeguard with a finishing glaze or coat of polyurethane.
9. Dress up a plain-Jane upholstered side chair by attaching interesting gimp (an ornamental braid or cord) fringe or other trim along the bottom of the seat using a hot-glue gun.
10. Faux paint old wooden furniture.
11. Paint mismatched dining room chairs bold colors (all the same or coordinating colors).
12. Stencil your children's names on the chair backs or add a motif.
13. Craft shops have small glue-on toys, animals, numbers, and initials.
14. Paint a wooden chair with an interesting shape in different colors and patterns like a Victorian house.
15. For color combination ideas, pick the colors already in your scheme.
16. Some paint companies put out booklets of historic color combinations

check these out for instant inspiration.
17. Paint vertical stripes on an old or RTA chest or nightstand using tape, a brilliant color or two, and a very steady hand wielding a paintbrush.
18. Measure off the stripes using a ruler and a pencil to make light marks.
19. Cover tables in flat-weave rugs like dhurries needlepoint or chain-stitch rugs to transform them into desks and display areas for framed family photos.
20. Use a deep glass-fronted china cabinet to hold a small TV or serve as a minibar in the living room, punching a hole in the back to slip through the wires for any appliances.
21. Display glasses and ice buckets.
22. Use pillows to convert lumber into a sofa of sorts outside or inside, using flatter pillows for seats and backs and fluffier ones for decoration and added comfort.

**General Actions**

1. Decide where to add refurbished furniture pieces in your home.
2. Safeguard with a finishing glaze or coat of polyurethane when decoupageing an old dresser or dressing table.
3. Use a hot-glue gun to attach interesting gimp (an ornamental braid or cord) fringe or other trim along the bottom of a side chair's seat.
4. Check out paint companies' booklets of historic color combinations for inspiration.
5. Measure off stripes using a ruler and a pencil to make light marks when painting vertical stripes on an old or RTA chest or nightstand.

**Food Safety**

1. Wash hands, utensils, containers, and cooking vessels every time handling raw poultry meat or fish.
2. Refrigerate or freeze perishable foods until ready to cook.
3. Thaw frozen foods in microwave, refrigerator, or under cold running water.
4. Never thaw food outside the refrigerator.
5. Dispose of spoiled or expired foods.
6. Purchase foods with longest expiration date.
7. Don't buy open or damaged packages.
8. Throw out raw eggs if cracked.
9. Keep refrigerator temperature below 40°F (44°C).
10. Use thermometer in refrigerator and adjust thermostat as necessary.
11. Scrub and wash utensils, cooking vessels, cutlery, and cutting boards thoroughly with soap and water.
12. Use separate cutting board for ready-to-eat or raw foods.

Clean your shipping container before use.

A clean shipping container is essential for safe and efficient transportation of goods.

Make sure that any dirt, dust, or other forms of detritus are removed from your shipping container. We suggest using a strong bristled broom and work your way from the back end of the container. It may be dusty inside so we also recommend that you wear a dust mask of some form. If you have access to a pressure washer or can borrow or rent one it will expedite the cleaning process greatly. For safety we recommend wearing some type of goggles or safety glasses. You’re going to be working in a confined area and anything you spray loose may bounce around – eye protection is important.

Start at the back of the container and work your way towards the doors. Pay special attention to the corners and seams. Also keep an eye open for any signs of excessive wear in the floor. Once the inside dries you may want to consider repairing any potentially weak spots.

After the inside is sprayed out we recommend cleaning the outside next. The high pressure hose will expose and possibly remove any loose paint or corrosion on your container. Inspect both the inside and outside of the shipping container for signs of rust or corrosion. If you do find any rust it can be treated with apple cider vinegar or white vinegar a natural rust remover.

Apply the vinegar to the rust and rub it with a cloth or strong brush. If vinegar doesn’t do the trick or isn’t fast enough for you try rubbing the rust spots on your cargo container with aluminum foil.

Once the container is completely dry inside and out go over the shipping container with a medium grit sandpaper. Either an orbital sander or belt sander will speed up the process. You don’t need to remove all of the paint but we do recommend attacking any spots on your container where the paint is peeling flaking or showing signs of wear.

After you’ve finished sanding your shipping container apply a primer coat of paint. The primer coat will help give it a stronger seal and base to prevent any moisture or corrosion in the future.

Finally after the primer coat is dry apply a thick exterior paint to the inside and outside of your storage container. Most exterior paints will work however if there’s any question it’s best to ask a professional or sales associate at the place where you purchased the paint.

Clean(shipping,container)

7. Wash off dirt and debris before cleaning the pavement

**Oil Stain Removal Methods**

1. Poultice method (for fresh or stubborn stains)
	* Use: kitty litter, acetone lacquer thinner or xylene, sheet of plastic
2. Household detergent method (for small stains)
	* Use: detergent, bucket, hose, steel brush
3. Degreaser or microbial cleaner method (for large stains)
	* Use: degreaser or microbial cleaner, bucket, hose, steel brush

**Precautions**

1. Wear protective clothing and gear when using degreasers
2. Keep pets and small children away from chemicals
3. Call poison control if accidents occur (1-800-222-1222)

Clean and store fresh basil.
Examine it and remove any dead or yellow leaves that you find.

Blanch and freeze the leaves.

Remove them with a slotted spoon and transfer them directly to a large bowl with water and ice in it.

Place basil leaves in a freezer-safe container or ziplock bag.

Dry your basil.

Keep the leaves as intact as possible and store them in canning jars.

Pull off any yellow or spotted leaves before drying your basil.

Keep fresh basil in water.
Clean stems of basil and trim off their bases.
Place them in a glass jar with about 1 inch (25 cm) to 2 inches (51 cm) of water at the bottom.
Basil stems will keep for up to two weeks if they are kept at room temperature and out of direct sunlight.

Make “basil cubes” In a food processor add 1 cup (250 ml) of basil leaves and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of grape seed oil.
Process this mixture until the basil leaves are in small bits then add 1 tablespoon (15 ml) water and process again to make a paste.
Pack the mixture tightly into an ice cube tray and freeze it.

Once the cubes are frozen transfer them into a freezer-safe container or ziplock bag to store them for easy use.
Basil cubes will keep in the freezer for approximately three to four months.

Decide how you want the room to feel. What kind of mood do you want your room to convey? Colors can create a sense of calm or rev up your mood. Decide if you want to feel soothed when you spend time in your room or if you want to feel peppy and full of energy.

Select a color scheme. Color family and tone are important factors in how a room will look and feel. Colors will also range from light to medium to dark. Accent colors or trim colors should have the same tone as the wall and ceiling but you can use color intensity or color families that complement each other to create contrast.
Color tone is either warm, cool, or neutral. Warm tones can create a cozy feel while cool tones can make a room feel bigger. Choosing coordinating colors of the same intensity can make a room feel more spacious. Large rooms can look very dramatic and dynamic if there are sharp contrasts between the intensity of the trim and the wall color.
Pick a color family to create feeling. Different color families affect how people feel, some colors are warmer and others cooler, and these qualities are important for conveying a mood. Reds are hot or warm colors typically. Red is also a very hot color in terms of creating a feeling in a room. Red can feel romantic and dramatic or lively and exciting.
Blue is a cool color and conveys a sense of calm and peace. Like the perfect clear light blue of a summer sky or the deep blue of the ocean, the soothing quality of blues won’t vary much with intensity.
Try green colors for a good balance between warm and cool. Because green is the result of a warm color (yellow) and a cool color (blue), it is an excellent choice for rooms with a neutral feel.
Yellow is an energy color as well as a comforting hue. Yellow is a great choice for rooms that could use some brightening up while still feeling soft and tranquil.

**Replace Disposable Air Filters**

* Replace disposable air filters.
* A cleanable air filter is advertised as “washable” “permanent” and/or “reusable”
* Don’t wash paper or otherwise disposable air filters.
* Avoid vacuuming them as well.
* Washing disposable air filters can actually clog them as well as cause mold.
* Disposable filters can tear under the pressure of vacuuming or compressed air.
* At a low pressure this may work temporarily but it’s not a long-term solution.

**Clean or Replace Car Air Filter**

* Clean or change your car air filter regularly.
* Clean or change your filter every 12,000 to 15,000 miles or more often if you travel on dusty roads or in polluted areas.
* Disposable filters should be replaced whereas permanent filters can be vacuumed or washed.

**Clean or Replace Home Air Filter**

* Clean or change your home air filter routinely.
* Clean or change your filter every three months and more frequently in-season.
* Clean or change the furnace filter monthly during the heating season.
* If your filter is disposable replace it.
* If it’s reusable you can vacuum or wash it.

**Clean or Replace Furnace Filter**

* Clean or change the furnace filter monthly during the heating season.
* If your filter is disposable replace it.
* If it’s reusable you can vacuum or wash it.
* More frequent changing is needed if your filter is exposed to a lot of dust or pet hair.

**Failing to Clean Air Filters Can Cause Problems**

* Failing to clean your air filters in the home can cause HVAC failure or even fire.

**Cleaning Engineered Hardwood Floors**

1. Purchase a manufacturer-recommended liquid cleaner.
2. Check with the manufacturer for specific cleaner recommendations.
3. Buy liquid cleaning products designed for engineered hardwood floors at local hardware stores or larger supply stores like Lowe's or Home Depot.
4. Scrub spills and stains with the liquid cleaner.

7. Don't leave excess liquid cleaner on the floor after cleaning a stain

wipe it up immediately with a clean paper towel or cloth.

**Important Notes**

1. Don't use cleaning products designed for tile or vinyl flooring, as they may damage engineered hardwood floors.
2. If you have questions about substituting cleaning products, contact the floor manufacturer and ask which liquid cleaning products may be safely used on their floors.

**Carpet Stain Removal**

1. Remove as much dirt, debris, or liquid from the carpet as possible.
2. Clean up solid material over the stain.
3. Vacuum dry crumbly material.
4. Scrape sticky areas with a Popsicle stick or butter knife.
5. Soak up excess liquid with a paper towel.
6. Blot the affected area.
7. Apply a carpet stain removal solution to the stained area.
8. Spray the stain with your solution (but don't drown it).
9. Allow the solution to soak into the stain for 10 minutes or recommended time on the bottle.
10. Keep children and pets away from carpeted areas topped with store-bought solution.
11. Blot the stained area with a paper towel rag or special carpet-cleaning tool.
12. Apply the solution again if the stain is still visible, and continue blotting once it has soaked for the recommended amount of time.
13. Keep a dry cloth or rag nearby to prevent the carpet from getting soaked.
14. Dab a washcloth in distilled water and blot over the freshly-cleaned area to rinse off any remnants of cleaning solution.
15. Blot the area dry with a clean paper towel or washcloth to dry the carpet.

**General**

1. Vacuum up dry crumbly material.
2. Scrape sticky areas with a Popsicle stick or butter knife.
3. Soak up excess liquid with a paper towel.
4. Use a white cloth or paper towel without any designs or ink printing.
5. Avoid using bleach unless you have a pure white carpet.

Consult your manufacturer’s guide or contractor. If you installed your countertops yourself then keep a photo of the concrete mix and surface coating so that you can consult it for reference. Use pH wipes. These are wipes that are sold in hardware and sometimes grocery stores. They come pre-moistened and are designed to be gentle on natural stone surfaces. In a bowl or bucket mix 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of mild dishwashing liquid into warm water. You can then dip a soft cloth or sponge into this mixture and use it to wipe down your countertops.
Wring it out so that the cloth or sponge is damp not soaking wet before wiping. This is a mild method that can work for both sealed and unsealed types of concrete countertops. This is a great way to clean prior to putting on a new coat of sealant.
Be very careful using heavily textured scrubbing pads as they may leave scratches and marks behind. Polish in small circles. Vacuum out the pantry.
Use a vacuum cleaner with a hose and an angular nozzle attachment to clean the walls, baseboards, and corners of the pantry or cupboard. Clean under all shelving liners, removing any old liners and vacuuming beneath them. If the liners are in bad shape, replace them.

Clean or change the furnace filter monthly during the heating season.
If your filter is disposable replace it.
If it’s reusable you can vacuum or wash it.
More frequent changing is needed if your filter is exposed to a lot of dust or pet hair.
Failing to clean your air filters in the home can cause HVAC failure or even fire.

Use evergreen branches.
If you want to decorate without a wreath but don’t want to stray too far from the look of seasonal greenery you can use evergreen branches to spruce up your door.
If you live in an urban area you can purchase artificial branches or if you have access to trees snip off four or five branches that are each around three feet in length.
Use ribbons or push pins to fix the evergreen branches to your front door.
If you like tie a red ribbon around the branches to give them the look of a seasonal bouquet.

Search inside. Keep an eye out for a metal box usually flush with the wall. The box will have a metal door to keep the breakers or fuses protected.
Check your garage for the circuit breaker or fuse box. It might also be in a storage room, basement, or hallway.
If you can't find your box in one of these areas look again or see if you can spot where the power connects to your house from outside.
Check for your box in the surrounding areas.
If you live in an apartment check in a cupboard or hallway.
Search outside. Depending on how old your house is your circuit breaker or fuse box could be outside.
Check next to the meter box for your house.
If you have trouble finding your circuit breaker or fuse box ask a neighbor where theirs is.
If you live in a neighborhood with houses built in the same era the boxes may be in similar locations.
Call an electrician if you can't find your circuit breaker or fuse box.
